Award.AwardTitle: A Summer Workshop on the Analysis of Longitudinal Study of American Youth (LSAY) Data

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
The present project will support a training workshop on the Longitudinal Study of American Youth (LSAY) data set for advanced graduate students, early career scholars, and other interested researchers. Since 1987, LSAY has followed a national probability sample of 7th and 10th grade public school students, and is the longest-running and most comprehensive data set available to examine the factors that contribute to student and young adult interest in and understanding of science, technology, engineering, mathematics, and medicine. The LSAY is distinctive in its measurement of home, school, peer, and community variables over more than two decades, making it ideal for analyses that seek to understand the interaction between and among these factors.

The comprehensive and longitudinal nature of the LSAY data set can present challenges to researchers unfamiliar with LSAY, such as the breadth of measures and the particular statistical procedures appropriate for analyses of change over time. To address this, this project will recruit 20 researchers for a 5-day workshop, hosted by the Inter-university Consortium for Political and Social Research (ICPSR) at the University of Michigan. Topics will include: (1) an introduction to the structure of the LSAY data set; (2) participants' achievement in science and mathematics, including the psychometric basis for these measures; (3) the coding of the many open-ended items in the LSAY; (4) the presence and use of geographic and location data; (5) measurement errors in repeated, longitudinal studies, and appropriate methods to address such errors.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The Longitudinal Study of American Youth (LSAY) has followed a national sample of 7th grade and 10th grade public school students for the last 26 years to improve our understanding of how American students develop an interest in science, engineering, and mathematics and how they acquire skills in those areas. The LSAY has provided important information about factors that encourage or impede student learning about science and mathematics and how they successfully enter into careers in these fields. The NSF has invested slightly more than $16 million in the collection of these data over the last three decades.

This grant supported a one-week summer workshop at the University of Michigan in 2012 for 19 younger scholars and leaders in informal science education. The workshop was designed to provide a thorough introduction to the logic and structure of the LSAY data set, which includes more than 12,000 pieces of information about each of the 5,100 students included in the continuing LSAY study. It is a large and complex data set and its use within the educational research community can be enhanced through a workshop experience that provides a broad introduction and some targeted skill development related to the use of large longitudinal data sets. A set of follow-up questionnaires to workshop participants found that almost all of the participants were using their new skills in their teaching or work and some had published articles. One participant is supervising a graduate student who is using the LSAY data in her dissertation.

Longitudinal research provides important insights about the long-term impact of various school practices and programs. The LSAY has become a valuable national resource because it is one of only a few data sets that can assess the impact of selected school experiences on student outcomes 20 years after the completion of high school. For example, recent analyses published from LSAY data show that 8th grade algebra and 12th grade calculus are important gateways for a student who wishes to become a professional scientist, engineer, or mathematician. Workshops such as the one supported by this grant expand the number of scholars and analysts who can make use of the LSAY and similar data sets to explore questions that are important to the development of sound science education policy in the United States.
